issue.title: Update PostgreSQLAdapter#extensions to include schema name
issue.body:
This allows the schema dumper's generated `enable_extension` statements
to include the schema name, if different from `current_schema`.

### Motivation / Background

Fixes #52312.

When extensions are created within a specific schema, the `enable_extension` statement generated by the schema dumper should include the schema name.

### Detail

See #52312

### Additional information

body:
I think this can be addressed by the above PR â€” let me know if this looks reasonable, and I can add corresponding tests.

I've also noticed a few things while setting up this test case:

1. The `disable_extension` method doesn't appear to handle schema names, so rolling back a migration with `enable_extension` with a named schema doesn't actually drop the extension. I can add a fix for this in the same PR or in a separate one if this is considered a separate issue.
2. Perhaps this is unintentional, but `create_schema` is not handled by the command recorder, but rather executed as-is. Are schemas not meant to be created in migrations?

Thanks for the review.

> The disable_extension method doesn't appear to handle schema names, so rolling back a migration with enable_extension with a named schema doesn't actually drop the extension. I can add a fix for this in the same PR or in a separate one if this is considered a separate issue.

The `disable_extension` method is also schema name aware, but the generated SQL statements handle schema names differently.
While `enable_extension` uses "create extension if not exists ... schema ...", `drop_extension` just calls the extension name like "schema_name.extension_name".
Would you open another pull request to make `disable_extension` handle schema name the same way as `enable_extension` does?

```ruby
class EnableHStoreExtension2 < ActiveRecord::Migration[8.0]
  def up
    create_schema 'testschema'
    enable_extension 'testschema.hstore'
  end
  def down
    disable_extension 'testschema.hstore'
    drop_schema 'testschema'
  end
end
```

- bin/rails db:migrate that calls up method
```sql
CREATE SCHEMA "testschema"
CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS "hstore" SCHEMA testschema
```

- bin/rails db:rollback that calls down method
```sql
DROP EXTENSION IF EXISTS "testschema.hstore"
DROP SCHEMA "testschema" CASCADE
```

> Perhaps this is unintentional, but create_schema is not handled by the command recorder, but rather executed as-is. Are schemas not meant to be created in migrations?

Actually I'm not sure if it is intentional but create_schema can be called within the migration so it would be nice if it is reversible.

- This migration is not reversible.

```ruby
class EnableHStoreExtension < ActiveRecord::Migration[8.0]
  def change
    create_schema 'myschema'
    enable_extension 'myschema.hstore'
  end
end
```

> The `disable_extension` method is also schema name aware, but the generated SQL statements handle schema names differently. While `enable_extension` uses "create extension if not exists ... schema ...", `drop_extension` just calls the extension name like "schema_name.extension_name".

That's actually incorrect --- weirdly, `DROP EXTENSION` [doesn't accept a schema name](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-dropextension.html).

> Would you open another pull request to make `disable_extension` handle schema name the same way as `enable_extension` does?

I'll follow up shortly with a PR that makes `enable_extension` reversible and allows `drop_extension` to take a schema name (which will get chopped off in the generated SQL).

issue.title: Make create_schema / drop_schema reversible in migrations
issue.body:

issue.title: Allow disable_extension to be called with schema-qualified name
issue.body:
Note that the PostgreSQL DROP EXTENSION statement does not accept a schema name (see https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-dropextension.html). Since we allow `enable_extension` to be called with a schema-qualified name, this commit allows `disable_extension` to be similarly called with a schema-qualified name, but the schema name is chopped off in the generated SQL statement.

See #52312 for context.

### Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:
